headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to CenturyLink's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Tony Davis, Vice
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to CenturyLink's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Tony Davis, Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr. Davis, you may begin.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sahid, and good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to our call today to discuss CenturyLink's fourth quarter 2015 results released earlier this afternoon. The slide presentation we will be reviewing during the prepared remarks portion of today's
componenttext:
Thank you, Sahid, and good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to our call today to discuss CenturyLink's fourth quarter 2015 results released earlier this afternoon. The slide presentation we will be reviewing during the prepared remarks portion of today's call is available in the Investor Relations section of our corporate website at ir.centurylink.com. At the conclusion of our prepared remarks today, we will open the call for Q&A. 
As you move to Slide 2, you'll find our safe harbor language. We will be making certain forward-looking statements today, particularly as they pertain to guidance for the fourth quarter and full year 2016 and other outlooks in our business. We ask that you review our disclosure found on this slide as well as in our press release and in our SEC filings, which describe factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those projected by us in our forward-looking statements. 
Moving to Slide 3, we ask that you also note that our earnings release issued earlier this afternoon and the slide presentation and remarks made during this call contain certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliation between the non-GAAP financial measures and the GAAP financial measures are available in our earnings release and in our website at ir.centurylink.com. 
Now moving to Slide 4. Your host for today's call is Glen Post, Chief Executive Officer and President of CenturyLink. Joining Glen today will be Stewart Ewing, CenturyLink's Chief Financial Officer. Our call today will be available for telephone replay through February 18, 2016, and a webcast replay of our call will be available through March 3, 2016. Anyone listening to a taped or webcast replay or reading a written transcript of this call should note that all information presented is current only as of February 10, 2016, and should be considered valid only as of this date, regardless of the date heard or viewed. 
Moving now to Slide 5, I'll now turn the call over to Glen Post. Glen?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Toni, and thank you for joining our call today as we discuss our fourth quarter results. I'll make a few remarks about 2015 and discuss 2016 objectives and our guidance. Beginning on Slide 6, 2015 was really a year of 2 very different halves fo
componenttext:
Thank you, Toni, and thank you for joining our call today as we discuss our fourth quarter results. I'll make a few remarks about 2015 and discuss 2016 objectives and our guidance. Beginning on Slide 6, 2015 was really a year of 2 very different halves for CenturyLink. In the first half, our sales and revenue trends were softer than we anticipated, entering the year during 2014 as part of our ongoing review of our business. We had identified an opportunity to improve the structure of our sales force when we began to implement this change in late 2014. Our sales organization realignment was more complex. It look longer than anticipated, and by midyear, operating expenses were out of alignment with our revenue outlook for the remainder of 2015, and we began to take aggressive corrective action in the second half of the year. And the benefits of the realignment, along with new leadership, began to take hold when we approved our overall sales performance and we increased our sales funnel of opportunities and enhanced our revenue trends. 
At the same time, we were also successful in taking costs out of the business. We reduced planned operating expenses in the second half of 2015 by more than $125 million, then the full $125 [ph] million target we had set in August. These actions have just delivered very strong results from the fourth quarter as revenues, cash flows and adjusted earnings per share all exceeded our expectations for the quarter. As we will highlight in more detail later in the call, we saw good in performance from our Consumer segment during the quarter. Growth in Prism TV customers along with higher average revenue per customer drove year-over-year consumer revenue growth. Also, for fourth quarter, business high-bandwidth data services grew approximately 9% year-over-year. So overall, we achieved significant improvement in the second half of 2015 compared to the first half of the year. 
Continuing on now to Slide 7, we also continue to focus on driving higher speeds across our network as we ended 2015 with 940,000 GPON addressable households and 490,000 GPON addressable businesses. And we provided more than 30% of our service area or addressable units with speeds of 40 megabytes or higher. We believe that's a speed that in the marketplace is sufficient to address most of our customers' actual needs. Additionally, we completed our $1 billion share repurchase authorization in early December and we returned a total of $2 billion to CenturyLink shareholders in 2015 through dividends and share repurchases. As you know, in early November, we announced we were beginning a strategic review process of our data centers and colocation business. This decision was made as part of our continued efforts to proactively manage our portfolio of assets to better position the company to compete to achieve profitable growth and drive our shareholder value. We made good progress with the process since our November announcement. We have established a separate data center/co-location organization, including a separate management team. We're also nearly complete with carve-out financial statements for our data centers and colocation business to provide -- the potential to acquire our partners. We've spoken to a number of interested parties, who expressed interest in all options, ranging from an outright purchase of our data centers and colo business, a partnership and/or a joint venture. This is an ongoing process and could result in any one of these outcomes, including the potential sale of a portion of our -- all of our data center business. 
Also as we have said, we could ultimately choose to retain these assets and related operations. As we outlined in November, we believe in the macro trends of the data center colocation industry and the importance of the surface and our hybrid IT solutions. But we do not believe we must own the colocation facilities to provide the full range of services our customers need to manage their IT functions. We expect to formally engage interested parties within the next 2 weeks or so. 
Continuing on now to Slide 8. As we enter 2016, we thought it might be useful to share with you a broader view of how we think about our business and operational focus for 2016 and beyond. First, I think it's important that we declare for ourselves why we're here what we are trying to accomplish and what we are trying to accomplish as an organization. And for us, that purpose is to improve the lives of our customers by connecting them to the digital world, whether it's providing connections or services on top of that connection using the power of the digital world to improve our customers' lives and businesses, is really what were all about. We expect to accomplish this purpose through a 2-part, mutually reinforcing mission. First, we provide our customers a gateway to the digital world by enabling fast, highly reliable broadband connections that are automated and easy to use. We also have significant opportunity to take a leadership position on this front, and our principal focus going forward will be to provide our customers the very best network experience; second, we will complement our strong access position by deploying less capital-intensive investments, higher growth solutions that deliver customers a full range of technology-focused services, such as managed network and hosting, cloud, IT services and video along with over-the-top applications and content. We believe this approach will allow us to deliver the full range of services to our customers, while also allowing us to prioritize capital to improve the Network Services offerings that are at the heart of our customer relationships. 
Continuing on to Slide 9. Looking at our purpose from a financial point of view, our focus is to create long-term shareholder value through both revenue growth and strong cash flow generation. I won't emphasize this last point. The focus of our business is to drive long-term free cash flow generation that enable us to continue to invest in our business and sustain our strong dividend. And we will prioritize investments and operational initiatives to support that outcome. We believe we can accomplish our goals to focus on 3 key operational initiatives. First, we will maximize market penetration of our network and adjacent services to drive growth. To accomplish this, we plan to maximize penetration in areas where we have invested in and enabled broadband capabilities. We will also continue to focus on investments, while enabling fast, reliable broadband connectivity. And we will enable other technology-focused solutions such as managed network, hosting cloud, IT services and video using capital position solutions and partnerships. 
Our second key initiative is to create exceptional customer experiences. As part of this effort, we plan to simplify our products, our processes and our systems, and we will continue our evolution through a single orchestration layer that automates the end-to-end customer experience that enables them access the complement of the services for cable providers. This will take time, but we have a roadmap in place to significantly improve our customer experience over the next couple of years. 
Finally, redeploy a disciplined approach to our operating and capital investments to deliver profitable growth, first, by investing more capital to enable high-bandwidth network connectivity and pursuing capital-light investment approaches for a complementary adjacent services. Allocating capital based on the best returns on investment and opportunities in key strategic objectives will be key. We also expect to gain revenue and operating expense efficiencies and improve cash flow operations through more aggressive systems consolidation, automation and process improvement. We have a clear strategic direction, and we believe by focusing on the operational areas, we will be able to build on CenturyLink's strong foundation and deliver value for both our customers and our shareholders. 
Finally, we'll focus on specific actions to drive sales and revenue growth of our strategic products in service in 2016 and beyond. We expect to drive further penetration of our consumer business and GPON footprint of over 900,000 households and almost 500,000 businesses and our 3 million households enabled for Prism TV service. And we expect to continue to expand high-bandwidth data services, GPON and Prism, enabling further revenue upside opportunities. We also believe we can continue sales momentum from the second half of 2015 and drive increased sales productivity through better go-to-market alignment, leveraging products, specialists and enabling additional sales in sales performance tools. And we plan to focus on winning large deals through dedicated teams and system integration and value-added resellers -- our system at the integrators and value-added resellers. Expanded distribution partners will be key to this hitting our goals and driving this revenue. 
And 1 final item, I'm sure you saw our release this afternoon announcing our new president of sales and marketing, a new Chief Marketing Officer. We look forward to Dean Douglas and Bill Hurley joining our team next week, and I'm confident they will be key contributors to helping us achieve the actions I just discussed. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Stewart for discussion of our financial results and liquidity position as well as our guidance. Stewart?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Glen. Over the next few minutes, I will review the financial results for the fourth quarter, provide an overview of the first quarter and full year 2016 guidance we included in our earnings release issued earlier this afternoon and conclude my
componenttext:
Thank you, Glen. Over the next few minutes, I will review the financial results for the fourth quarter, provide an overview of the first quarter and full year 2016 guidance we included in our earnings release issued earlier this afternoon and conclude my remarks with a discussion of CenturyLink liquidity position. 
Regarding our guidance, we were pleased that our full year expectations for 2016 are in line or better than current average analyst estimates. 
Now moving to Slide 11, I will review a few highlights from our fourth quarter results. Please note that I'll be reviewing the results, excluding special items, as outlined in our earnings release and associated financial schedules. As Glen mentioned earlier, we achieve strong results for the fourth quarter and operating revenues were $4.48 billion on a consolidated basis, 9/10 of a percent increase from fourth quarter 2014 operating revenues. This increase was primarily driven by an increase in high-cost support revenues of approximately $60 million due to the recognition of CAF Phase II support during the fourth quarter 2015 along with strength in high-bandwidth data services and consumer strategic revenues. 
Core revenue, defined as strategic revenue plus legacy revenue, was $4.03 billion for the fourth quarter, a decline of only 0.5% from the year ago period. Strategic revenues grew 3% year-over-year, primarily driven by strength in strategic products, including high-speed data services, high-speed Internet and Prism TV. 
In the fourth quarter, we added approximately 16,000 Prism TV customers, while high-speed Internet customers declined about 22,000 during the quarter, partially as a result of tighter credit standards implemented in midyear 2015. We generated operative cash flow of approximately $1.82 billion for the fourth quarter and achieved an operating cash flow margin of 40.6%. Cash expenses for the fourth quarter declined to $72 million year-over-year primarily due to lower employee related costs. And on a sequential quarter basis, cash basis declined to $115 million or 4.1% from the third quarter of 2015. 
Free cash flow, defined as operating cash flow less cash paid for taxes, interest in capital expenditures along with other income, was 550 -- $591 million for the quarter. Adjusted diluted earnings per share for the fourth quarter was $0.80. As we have discussed on prior earnings calls, adjusted diluted EPS excludes special items and certain noncash purchase accounting adjustments as outlined in our press release and associated supplemental financial schedules. Additionally, as Glen mentioned earlier, we repurchased more than 10 million shares for an investment of nearly $280 million during the fourth quarter, which completed the $1 billion share repurchase program. 
Moving to Slide 12 and our Business segment. In fourth quarter, the Business segment generated $2.66 billion in operating revenues, which decreased $43 million or 1.6% from the same period a year ago. Fourth quarter strategic revenues for the segment increased 1.4% to $1.6 billion from fourth quarter 2014, driven by continued strength in high-bandwidth services such as MPLS and Ethernet, partially offset by the declines in low-bandwidth data services and wholesale repricing. Legacy revenues for the segment declined 6.2% from fourth quarter 2014 due primarily to continuing decline in access lines and lower long-distance revenues. Total Business segment expenses decreased from the year-ago period, driven primarily by lower employee-related expenses and CPE cost. Our segment margin was 44.1%, which was an increase from 43.6% a year ago. 
Now turn to Slide 13. Consumer generated $1.51 billion in total operating revenues, an increase of $19 million or 1.3% from fourth quarter 2014. Strategic revenues in this segment grew 6.3% year-over-year to $773 million, driven by year-over-year growth in high-speed Internet and Prism TV revenues. Legacy revenues for the Consumer segment declined only 3.4% from fourth quarter 2014 as access line and long-distance revenue declines were partially offset by select price increases. Operating expenses decreased $17 million or 2.8% compared to the same period a year ago. 
Now turning to Slide 14. For first quarter 2015, we expect operating revenues of $4.40 billion to $4.45 billion, core revenues of $3.95 billion to $4 billion and operating cash flow between $1.66 million and $1.72 billion. Adjusted diluted EPS is expected to range from $0.67 to $0.73. Our anticipated sequential decrease in first quarter operating revenues compared to fourth quarter 2015 is primarily due to declines in legacy, hosting and low-bandwidth data services more than offsetting the anticipated growth in revenues from high-bandwidth data services. We expect first quarter 2016 operating cash flow to be lower than fourth quarter 2015, primarily driven by the decline in revenues I just mentioned along with higher costs. Those higher costs include approximately $35 million from onetime favorable expense items in the fourth quarter, and in the first quarter, $25 million of higher payroll taxes and $20 million related to higher marketing costs. 
For full year 2016, we expect operating revenues of $17.5 billion to $17.8 billion and core revenues of $17.75 billion to $16 billion. Both are expected to be slightly lower compared to full year 2015 expected legacy revenue declines more than offsetting anticipated increases in the level of strategic revenue growth. Our operating cash flow for full year 2016 is expected to be $6.6 billion to $6.8 billion, lower than full year 2015, primarily driven by the continued decline in legacy and low-bandwidth data revenues. The company anticipates lower depreciation and amortization expense for full year 2016 compared to full year 2015, and adjusted diluted EPS for full year 2016 is projected to be $2.50 to $2.70. The expected lower full year operating cash flow for 2016, along with higher cash income taxes and anticipated 2016 capital expenditures of $3 billion, are expected to lower free cash flow to $1.8 billion to $2 billion. 
Now turning to Slide 15. Since we recently issued $235 million of debt to refinance upcoming maturities, we thought we would provide you with our plans for our maturities over the remainder of the year. Our total debt maturities for 2016 are approximately $1.4 billion. As I mentioned in January, we completed a $235 million debt issuance of 7%, Qwest core 4-year [ph] notes that will be used to refinance an upcoming May 1 maturity. That primarily leads us with an embark debt maturity of a little less than $1.2 billion on June 1. We expect to be opportunistic in the coming months in refinancing some or all of that debt as well at the CenturyLink parent level. It's important to note that with approximately $400 million as of -- drawn as of the end of 2015 on our $2 billion credit facility, we have the capacity to handle the June 1 maturity if needed. Additionally, since we completed our $1 billion share repurchase program in early December, we could also use available free cash flow for a portion of the June 1 maturity if necessary. 
as indicated by our 2016 guidance, we expect $600 million to $800 million of free cash flow after the cash dividend, which results in our dividend payout ratio in the low to mid-60% range in 2016, which is very sustainable. So we're confident that our solid cash flows continue to provide us the financial strength and flexibility to meet our business objectives and drive long-term shareholder value. 
That concludes our prepared remarks for the day. So at this time, I'll ask the operator to provide instructions for the Q&A portion of the call.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from David Barden from Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from David Barden from Bank of America.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess, a couple of questions if I could. For Stewart, just first, #1, as we kind of look at the 2016 guide, obviously, last year, we had an issue with kind of overestimating how the year was going to play out. So I was wondering if you can kind of ta
componenttext: So I guess, a couple of questions if I could. For Stewart, just first, #1, as we kind of look at the 2016 guide, obviously, last year, we had an issue with kind of overestimating how the year was going to play out. So I was wondering if you can kind of talk a little bit about what the base case expectations that you've modeled out for the economy and sales force ramp? And whether you're incoming head of revenue? Mr. Douglas has bought into these expectations, and kind of your comfort level of achievement. That will be #1. Second would be on the cash tax outlook and kind of the update on bonus tax depreciation, what's embedded in that free cash flow guidance? And then the last one, if I could, will just be kind of the meter data opportunity. I think we've been seeing a lot of the cable companies experimenting with data caps and metering higher-end usage. It seems like the FCC is not pushing back on this and it feels like it could be a big opportunity for telcos do, if nothing else, price underneath the cable umbrella and start to raise rates from high-end users. I was wondering if that's something that you guys are looking at as an opportunity and where it stands?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so, David, in terms of 2016 revenue guidance, I mean, I believe we do feel more comfortable with the revenue guidance that we have this year from the guidance that we provided in '15. We think we have some things in place from a sales standpoint. Our
componenttext: Yes, so, David, in terms of 2016 revenue guidance, I mean, I believe we do feel more comfortable with the revenue guidance that we have this year from the guidance that we provided in '15. We think we have some things in place from a sales standpoint. Our funnel continues to build and look good. We have a number of big deals that are in the funnel and hopefully, we can get the closure with some of those. We're also working on the provisioning, the audit and cash to get the sales that the salespeople make provisioned and in the billing quicker and hope to be able to get that done over the course of the next few months to where we can reduce our cycle times there. That will help. The other focus that we have is on churn reduction, so we are working there to try to keep the customers we have and try to make some of the price declines and credits that we've been issuing smaller. So we hope -- we're hopeful that we're attacking revenue, not just from a sales standpoint this year, but also from the standpoint of reducing churn as well as getting the orders into cash quicker. And we've also have a big team as we've talked about before that were launched to pursue larger opportunities. In terms of the guidance and the macroeconomic issues, I mean, we basically assumed that the economy stays about, like as it is at this point, so no real certificate changes there. Glen, I'll let you talk about Dean.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We've had discussions with Dean and Bill Hurley, and at a high level, they feel good about what we're projecting. They obviously have the aptitude to get into detail, but I know we've had discussions with them and they believe we have upside in a lot
componenttext: Yes. We've had discussions with Dean and Bill Hurley, and at a high level, they feel good about what we're projecting. They obviously have the aptitude to get into detail, but I know we've had discussions with them and they believe we have upside in a lot of areas, but they have not had a chance to really get into details of our projections at this point. And from the standpoint of -- just to kind of close out the revenue, we had some revenue growth this year in the fourth quarter. We did in the first quarter of 2015. We would expect probably second quarter 2016, we would reach a little bit of revenue growth. But in terms -- were going to be so close just in terms of projecting that we're going to hit stability and growth on a sequential basis quarter after quarter. It's really not possible for us to do it now, but we think that with the three-pronged approach that we have to really driving revenue, keeping the revenue we have, getting customers to build quicker, it will pay dividends for us from the standpoint of getting real momentum in terms of our revenue growth. In terms of cash taxes, our cash taxes for 2015 were $63 million. Based on the operating income guidance that we provided for 2016, we would expect cash taxes to be approximately $400 million at the low end of guidance and about $600 million at the high end of guidance. And as we say with the free cash flow that, that results in after the operating income, you result in the dividend payout ratio being in the low to mid-60s. I might add that dividend payout ratio in 2017, at this point, we would say we would be kind of in the low to mid-70s because, we think that cash taxes will increase somewhat in 2017, just because the impact of bonus depreciation will be less as it matures more.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, regarding the metered data plans, we are considering that for the second half of the year. We think it's important that our competition is using metered plans today. And we think, today, we have to explore and -- actually, we'll start some tria
componenttext: And David, regarding the metered data plans, we are considering that for the second half of the year. We think it's important that our competition is using metered plans today. And we think, today, we have to explore and -- actually, we'll start some trials later this year is our expectations.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Amir Rozwadowski from Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Amir Rozwadowski from Barclays.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Building upon the prior question around sort of thinking about the trajectory of the business from a top line perspective, how should we think about some of the opportunities that you've had in terms of reducing the cost in the business? And specifically,
componenttext: Building upon the prior question around sort of thinking about the trajectory of the business from a top line perspective, how should we think about some of the opportunities that you've had in terms of reducing the cost in the business? And specifically, if you do find yourself in a position, where you can get sort of stable top line growth can we pull forward expectation around the ability to return to EBITDA growth and operating income growth for the business?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we still think that we can hopefully, after we get to some level of revenue stability, continued stability in growth, that we can get to EBITDA stability within 12 to 18 months thereafter. But again, as I've said many times before, EBITDA sta
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we still think that we can hopefully, after we get to some level of revenue stability, continued stability in growth, that we can get to EBITDA stability within 12 to 18 months thereafter. But again, as I've said many times before, EBITDA stability is really dependent upon continued movement, continued improvement in sales of our strategic products over time, lessening the client and the rate of legacy revenue that we're seeing. And then also, the third leg of that is to basically continue to control our operating expenses to get to EBITDA stability.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I might add to that, the simplification of our processes, the automation of a lot of the end-to-end process into single platform, orchestration platform I mentioned earlier, those are the ways today we can take significant cost out of the business as well
componenttext: I might add to that, the simplification of our processes, the automation of a lot of the end-to-end process into single platform, orchestration platform I mentioned earlier, those are the ways today we can take significant cost out of the business as well as create a much better customer experience. So those are areas we're looking at for future cost control.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then if I may follow-up on the exploration of the strategic alternatives for the data center side, it sounds as though you're, based on your prepared comments moving forward, well on that front. Can you talk to us about the interest, perhaps, you may
componenttext: And then if I may follow-up on the exploration of the strategic alternatives for the data center side, it sounds as though you're, based on your prepared comments moving forward, well on that front. Can you talk to us about the interest, perhaps, you may or may not have seen in the marketplace? There've been a number of folks who either expressed a goal to do something similar, or at least have been rumored to potentially be doing something similar. So would love to hear sort of compare and contrast what you're hearing in the market in terms of receptivity would be very helpful.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, obviously, we're aware that there are other activity in the market with folks with data centers, colocation business out there possibly for sale. But I can tell you this, we are seeing a significant number of interest right now. And you never -- don'
componenttext: Yes, obviously, we're aware that there are other activity in the market with folks with data centers, colocation business out there possibly for sale. But I can tell you this, we are seeing a significant number of interest right now. And you never -- don't  know until you get into negotiations, which we hope starts in a couple of weeks that process. But we are seeing interest from strategic buyers as well as financial buyers and ask a lot of questions, 1 to indicate the room, want to start talking with us about the opportunity. So again, you never know, but interest level is high right now.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Simon Flannery from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Simon Flannery from Morgan Stanley.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the buyback program is over. And-- I understand you're waiting for the result of the data center, but can you just talk more broadly about your leverage target? And given the credit environment out here, how are you thinking about where you want that l
componenttext: So the buyback program is over. And-- I understand you're waiting for the result of the data center, but can you just talk more broadly about your leverage target? And given the credit environment out here, how are you thinking about where you want that leverage to be over time in terms of how much of the sort of this free? And how much of the data center sales might go to maintaining sort of 3 turns? Or do you want to bring that down under 3 turns over time? And on broadband, can you just update if you gave us some good stats on the speeds and the built out there. How are you thinking about returning broadband growth? We've seen a pretty tough quarter so far for the telcos relative to the cable, and we touched on that on an earlier question. But you're always getting the speeds up, so what can you do on the channel side, marketing side to turn that back to growth? And maybe you can just weave in CAF II progress into that?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Simon. So the leverage target, I mean, we still have a goal of about 3x. But what we said is as the business -- as EBITDA declines somewhat, we were basically willing to go over 3x if we saw that EBITDA overtime was going to turn around and if you br
componenttext: Yes, Simon. So the leverage target, I mean, we still have a goal of about 3x. But what we said is as the business -- as EBITDA declines somewhat, we were basically willing to go over 3x if we saw that EBITDA overtime was going to turn around and if you bring us back to 3x are lower. So we will look at the proceeds from the sale of the data. At this point, we don't have any goals to reduce our leverage below 3x. I mean, we still think that with what we've done with our debt maturities, we have plenty of liquidity and generate plenty of free cash flow. And we'll wait and see what happens with respect to the data centers fails, and then we'll decide from there what we do more or less with a $600 million to $800 million of free cash flow that we expect to have in '16 after the payment of the dividend as well as the free cash flow associated with the -- as well as the cash associated with the potential sale of the data center.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Regarding the broadband, first of all, we believe that we have real opportunity to take advantage of the investments we've made in recent months in GPON and Prism. We paid us down about 950,000 homes with GPON with a 1 gig speeds, [indiscernible] 780,000
componenttext: Regarding the broadband, first of all, we believe that we have real opportunity to take advantage of the investments we've made in recent months in GPON and Prism. We paid us down about 950,000 homes with GPON with a 1 gig speeds, [indiscernible] 780,000 of those homes. That's a 17% [ph] increase from the third quarter in terms of GPON homes passed. We grew our Prism markets, market exposure with GPON capabilities from 600,000 to 700,000 in the fourth quarter. And we're seeing really strong take rates where we have GPON in the zones and businesses, so that's a very positive for us. We average about right now just in this early on, we realized we got about [ph] 15% penetration in our GPON markets  of the GPON products. So it's growing. And that's just, as you know, most of it is rolled out this past year. So we're really pleased with that. Also if you look at our market share data, our market share and a lot of the cities we're in is very low. We think we have upside there going in these businesses. And we also attach or connecting more of the MTUs and MTUs within our markets that we believe give us a lot of opportunity where we've had very little market share there. 30% -- more than 30% of our households that we serve are in MTUs so that's a real market opportunity there as well that we were on. So those are some of the things we're doing we really believe can really turn around the broadband growth.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Something you may have positive adds for 2016? Or is it too early to say?
componenttext: Something you may have positive adds for 2016? Or is it too early to say?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we will. I think it's a little early, but I think we are on the path the positive net adds in '16.
componenttext: I think we will. I think it's a little early, but I think we are on the path the positive net adds in '16.

componenttext: Two questions. First on the high-speed data growth side, you saw some acceleration in the quarter. Can you provide us for retail versus wholesale? And do you expect that trend to continue in the first half of the year? And then on CapEx, can you provide some color on where that $3 billion will go in terms of different bucket? And how should we think about incremental fiber deployments? And any trends you could highlight in terms of cost of deployment coming down and potentially accelerating that trend?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: So Batya year, terms of the CapEx color, basically, in 2016, a little bit over the over $2 billion or so of the capital budget will be what we call revenue enablement support. Probably of that 2 point -- of that  approximately $2 billion, basically, broadband enablement connection and capacity is about $1.2 billion or so. And Ethernet and MPLS enablement is probably about $600 million or so. So we're going to expect to continue to spend capital to bring higher and invest in the access part of our business to basically be able to prove either fiber or other technologies overtime and be able to drive higher speeds for our customers.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Ana Goshko of Bank of America.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you laid out pretty well what the plan is for addressing the 2016 bond maturity, particularly with the state of credit markets right now. But wondering, 1, is there an interest rate level at which you -- in your mind, it becomes prohibitive to ref
componenttext: I think you laid out pretty well what the plan is for addressing the 2016 bond maturity, particularly with the state of credit markets right now. But wondering, 1, is there an interest rate level at which you -- in your mind, it becomes prohibitive to refinance that on an unsecured basis? And have you thought about moving into the unsecured market where you would like to get a better cost of capital?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Ana, we've looked at that and we're continuing to look at it some. And I guess, we've not made really any final decisions. But at this point, I mean, we would prefer to stay unsecured even if it might cost us a little bit more. Again, we can carry -- w
componenttext: So Ana, we've looked at that and we're continuing to look at it some. And I guess, we've not made really any final decisions. But at this point, I mean, we would prefer to stay unsecured even if it might cost us a little bit more. Again, we can carry -- we can really be opportunistic with this next -- with a little less than $1.2 billion that we will need to raise to refinance the embark maturity. Because again we have about $1.6 billion availability on the credit facility. Additionally, our highest free cash flow quarter of the year is the first quarter, because basically, our CapEx somewhat gets off a little bit of a slow start. We just have more for free cash flow in the first quarter. We probably generate over 50% of our free cash flow that we're going to generate in the first [ph] quarter, really. So we have a lot of options and we will look at secured options. But at this point, we're not leaning in that direction. Not to say we wouldn't go there overtime, but...

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, And also, I think, I heard it correctly. But any decisions on further shareholder return beyond the current dividend? Did you say that you're going to wait until you get through the data center process and potentially through this EMBARQ maturity as
componenttext: Okay, And also, I think, I heard it correctly. But any decisions on further shareholder return beyond the current dividend? Did you say that you're going to wait until you get through the data center process and potentially through this EMBARQ maturity as well before you decide what to do with excess free cash flow in the year?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Certainly, through the EMBARQ maturity. And in all likelihood, until we get much more color in terms of what's going to happen with the data center business.
componenttext: Yes. Certainly, through the EMBARQ maturity. And in all likelihood, until we get much more color in terms of what's going to happen with the data center business.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Rollins with Citi Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Rollins with Citi Research.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two, if I could. Just first, a housekeeping item. Can you talk about why depreciation may fall in 2016? And then secondly, if you go back, I think, it was a few weeks ago, the company filed a lengthy 8-K describing some changes to the board in pointed to
componenttext: Two, if I could. Just first, a housekeeping item. Can you talk about why depreciation may fall in 2016? And then secondly, if you go back, I think, it was a few weeks ago, the company filed a lengthy 8-K describing some changes to the board in pointed to some maybe differences in perspective. Can you provide us with more context maybe to what happened? And maybe some of the strategic issues that the company may or may not be wrestling with in the board room?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll take the first one, Mike, on depreciation. So basically, we would expect depreciation and amortization to be down somewhere between $200 million and $250 million, 2016 versus 2015. About $75 million of that decline is really a decline in the custo
componenttext: So I'll take the first one, Mike, on depreciation. So basically, we would expect depreciation and amortization to be down somewhere between $200 million and $250 million, 2016 versus 2015. About $75 million of that decline is really a decline in the customer list amortization that we have that was really part of the purchase price adjustments related to primarily the Qwest acquisition and the EMBARQ acquisition as well. The depreciation rate, the decline in depreciation really is due to some of our assets becoming fully depreciated and retired. So basically, that decline in depreciation that we have been  that did occur in 2015 is offset to a certain degree by the $3 billion that we expect in depreciation and the $3 billion we expected to invest in 2016 [indiscernible] So really about $100 million to $150 million decline really related to the -- just the depreciation part.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Mike, regarding Joe Zimmer's departure. First, Joe made a lot of contributions to our company for 12 years. The 12 years he was here, we appreciated them that and wish him the very best. As we stated in the 8-K that we filed, really, the connection wi
componenttext: And Mike, regarding Joe Zimmer's departure. First, Joe made a lot of contributions to our company for 12 years. The 12 years he was here, we appreciated them that and wish him the very best. As we stated in the 8-K that we filed, really, the connection with [indiscernible] review of the board slate, the nominating and governance committee recommended and the board ultimately concluded that Joe should just on for reelection at the 2016 meeting. The board felt the change would lead an environment with improved productivity and constructive dialogue. It was really just a board chemistry issue is what this was. And in no time has Joe raised any issue about the company's accounting or financial reporting either leading up to or following his resignation. Also, Joe didn't raise concerns about the company's strategy or succession planning prior to his resignation. It's not that I'm aware of board members were all aware of. His principal complaint related to the process, the board used to reach the conclusion that he would not be included on the 2016 slate. And I think actually in my comments to that, a lot of details in our 8-K that we filed on January 25 and you can maybe read all of that, bu that really contains exactly what happened in my view. And it includes Joe's comment as well.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could just follow-up with one other question. Do you keep tallies internally of the proportion of your footprint, where you have a comparable or better speed for broadband that you can market your customers? And is that something that you can share w
componenttext: If I could just follow-up with one other question. Do you keep tallies internally of the proportion of your footprint, where you have a comparable or better speed for broadband that you can market your customers? And is that something that you can share with us in terms of what that might look like? I realize you shared with us earlier some the stats on your GPON and some of the build there. But more broadly, do you have a sense of just how you fully stack up against the cable competitors?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, yes, we have that information and we use it continually. I don't have it here [indiscernible] total overall percentages and speeds. But we have that, the marketing department, sales, we use that continually to identify how where we build add
componenttext: First of all, yes, we have that information and we use it continually. I don't have it here [indiscernible] total overall percentages and speeds. But we have that, the marketing department, sales, we use that continually to identify how where we build additional capacity, how we go to market in advertising, all that pricing, all the comes into play and that's a very important part of our analysis.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike McCormack from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike McCormack from Jefferies.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just another thought, I guess, on the economy. I think somebody asked earlier, but any feedback you're getting from the bigger business customers with respect to any skittishness or nervousness on the part of making decisions or slowing down decision maki
componenttext: Just another thought, I guess, on the economy. I think somebody asked earlier, but any feedback you're getting from the bigger business customers with respect to any skittishness or nervousness on the part of making decisions or slowing down decision making? And the second part, just on the involuntary churn in the high-speed adds, just trying to get a sense of what it is that going on there? And perhaps how long that might persist?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, Mike, on the customers' perspective tot he economy, anybody connected with -- any company connected with the oil and gas business is skittish right now, obviously, and for good reason. So that we're seeing some of that in the oil and gas sec
componenttext: First of all, Mike, on the customers' perspective tot he economy, anybody connected with -- any company connected with the oil and gas business is skittish right now, obviously, and for good reason. So that we're seeing some of that in the oil and gas sector. Of course, it's not a major vertical. We do have some customers there, but it hasn't been a major vertical for us. Outside of that, we're not seeing a lot of concerns out there right now. We'll see what happens the next few months, but right now, we're seeing -- we were already seeing long decision-making time frames by businesses the last year or so, so that's not a change and we're still seeing that. But no major -- we're not getting major negative feedback from our customers at this point in time outside of the oil and gas sector. As far as the involuntary churn on the Internet speed, we hope we worked in most of it in the fourth [ph] quarter, so we don't those changes we made last year on the credit requirements and the higher prices, the price increases that we had last year, we think we worked through most of that. So hopefully, we'll see the first quarter -- that coming in the first quarter.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And were those customers, Glen, folks that been chosen some other provider and just started to stop paying without disconnecting? Or is there something else we should be thinking about?
componenttext: And were those customers, Glen, folks that been chosen some other provider and just started to stop paying without disconnecting? Or is there something else we should be thinking about?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was that and just folks who never paid. They just never paid and they come in and skipped service for 3 or 4 months and they don't have time to pay, and [indiscernible] so we put in stiffer requirements.
componenttext: It was that and just folks who never paid. They just never paid and they come in and skipped service for 3 or 4 months and they don't have time to pay, and [indiscernible] so we put in stiffer requirements.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Frank Louthan from chamber James.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Can you describe a little bit of the product and systems of simplification that you're looking at? And maybe how long that will take? And ultimately, the cost there? And then on the strategic review with the data center, what kind of economic benef
componenttext: Great. Can you describe a little bit of the product and systems of simplification that you're looking at? And maybe how long that will take? And ultimately, the cost there? And then on the strategic review with the data center, what kind of economic benefits could you expect to see from some sort of a partnership arrangement? I asked that part because I've never actually seen 1 work, so I'm curious what you think how that might work versus just not right sale.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Aamir Hussain here, our Chief Technology Officer, I will let him address the systems. It's a major undertaking for us. I can tell you this, we're already seeing benefits, but it will be a continual effort over the next 2 years, 2.5 years really. Aamir, yo
componenttext: Aamir Hussain here, our Chief Technology Officer, I will let him address the systems. It's a major undertaking for us. I can tell you this, we're already seeing benefits, but it will be a continual effort over the next 2 years, 2.5 years really. Aamir, you want to talk about that?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, both product and system simplifications are really driven by the rationalization of the products, the networks and systems and applications we have. And the goal is to reduce fruition cycles and get revenue of the door as soon as possible. And we hav
componenttext: Yes, both product and system simplifications are really driven by the rationalization of the products, the networks and systems and applications we have. And the goal is to reduce fruition cycles and get revenue of the door as soon as possible. And we have multiple streams we are looking at products. We are looking at process, we are looking at systems. We're trying to use our portal platform and consolidate multiple portal, provide a great customer experience. And at the end of the day, the whole lead to cash process of being looked. At and every process within those processes are being combined to create a great experience for that customer. Again, that's just your systems, your processes, getting revenue in the door and enhancements into our current system's process with new technology to be able to provide better opportunities to our sales and operations folks to provide greater customer experience.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And part of the economic benefits on a joint venture on the data centers, it depends on what you mean by joint venture, I know it's a lot different approach to a joint venture. But the main thing that we would like to be able to do is continue to have a w
componenttext: And part of the economic benefits on a joint venture on the data centers, it depends on what you mean by joint venture, I know it's a lot different approach to a joint venture. But the main thing that we would like to be able to do is continue to have a wholesale opportunity with the -- within the centers that we own today. We would like to avoid the high level of capital expenditures that's required. We think we can drive higher returns by investing in those dollars in network and other areas, so that's really our view in there. And not only that, the valuations are significantly -- significant right now. And we think we can consider that now at the time to do it. We think it's a good business. It is good. The margins are good, we're growing, been growing this business some. So it's not what we're running from, but we just think the ownership of the assets, we don't think we have to own those assets. That's really the reason we're looking at selling those centers.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from [indiscernible] from Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from [indiscernible] from Crdit Suisse.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first one, I just wanted to make sure I heard you right. I think you said your preference was to refinance the EMBARQ notes at the parent level. Just wanted to understand the rationale for that? And whether what's your thought about doing the refinanc
componenttext: The first one, I just wanted to make sure I heard you right. I think you said your preference was to refinance the EMBARQ notes at the parent level. Just wanted to understand the rationale for that? And whether what's your thought about doing the refinancing at the EMBARQ level itself? Or potentially at a sort of an intermediate wholesale as well?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: So basically, we've been trying to just [indiscernible] acquisition over the years to simplify our capital structure somewhat. And frankly, it's really -- we've looked at the potential of refinancing down at the EMBARQ level. It creates another public ent
componenttext: So basically, we've been trying to just [indiscernible] acquisition over the years to simplify our capital structure somewhat. And frankly, it's really -- we've looked at the potential of refinancing down at the EMBARQ level. It creates another public entity that we have to do public filings all in all, and we just think it's not worth the effort of all of that as well as the right differentials that's not that significant. So we've been -- for the last 5 years or so, have been working to refinance debt on Qwest Corp. At Qwest Corp, the debt maturities there because it is still investment-grade. Everything else is -- the parent is not investment-grade. So we've been moving everything up there and we think that -- I mean, we've had really good with a good execution over the years. I mean, as I mentioned earlier, we'll see over time if we need to go into more secured product to get better rates. At this time, we don't think we need to, but we'll just monitor that over time.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate that. And then as far as the cash taxes for 2017 that you said it will be higher than 2016, but do you have sort of a preliminary number? I mean, should we [indiscernible] something in the 700 plus million range?
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate that. And then as far as the cash taxes for 2017 that you said it will be higher than 2016, but do you have sort of a preliminary number? I mean, should we [indiscernible] something in the 700 plus million range?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you look at your -- if you look at pretax and book income, possibly somewhere in the range of maybe 45% to 55% would be the effect of cash tax rate. But it's early yet and we will have to see. I mean, I'm sure it will change some over the year as we
componenttext: So if you look at your -- if you look at pretax and book income, possibly somewhere in the range of maybe 45% to 55% would be the effect of cash tax rate. But it's early yet and we will have to see. I mean, I'm sure it will change some over the year as we get closer to '17, but it will go up some. So the benefit of bonus depreciation to us over the life of the program is a little bit over $1 billion. And we figured we've got $250 million of the benefit in '15 and probably $450 million of the benefits in '16. So we've gotten -- we will have, by the end of '16, achieved about $700 million of the little bit over $1 billion deferral that we expect to get during the life of the bonus depreciation legislation. And that assumes our CapEx stays at about the same level as it is today.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Xavier from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Xavier from Wells Fargo.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick ones. In looking at the supplemental information, it looks like there was a sizable working capital outflow more than $500 million. Just curious if that was an anomaly? And if we can expect that to perhaps reverse in future periods?
componenttext: Just a couple of quick ones. In looking at the supplemental information, it looks like there was a sizable working capital outflow more than $500 million. Just curious if that was an anomaly? And if we can expect that to perhaps reverse in future periods? And then secondly, just back on the EMBARQ maturity for a second, Stewart, you mentioned perhaps using the revolver as a backstop. So I guess, just wanted to ask if that would be used only if the market were closed? Or would you perhaps look to use that even if the rate environment is not -- still not favorable to you?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the decline in working capital was basically on October 1 maturity of debt that we paid off, so that's why our working capital declined. In terms of the credit facility, I think, we've said we're going to keep about $1 billion of capacity on the credit
componenttext: So the decline in working capital was basically on October 1 maturity of debt that we paid off, so that's why our working capital declined. In terms of the credit facility, I think, we've said we're going to keep about $1 billion of capacity on the credit facility just for things like this. At times when the markets are not where we want to issue with the free cash flow that we'll have in 2016, even beyond the dividend payment, the $600 million to $800 million, I mean, we're not opposed to keeping it on the credit facility for some time if we need to in order to get a better rate and to get past the -- let the high-yield markets heal themselves somewhat.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our final question comes from Brett Feldman from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our final question comes from Brett Feldman from Goldman Sachs.

componenttext: Just a quick housekeeping question. I was hoping you can give us an update on the net funding status of the pension at the end of the year? And whether you anticipate making any cash contributions in 2016?

componenttext: Yes. No, we will file our K -- yes, the 26 is our target. So we'll file our K in a couple of weeks, and on all the pinch and disclose, the pages and pages of pension and disclosure will be in there. So I really don't have that at this point in time.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: And do you have a preliminary estimate to where you need to make a cash contribution? Or is that still being worked out?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We do not need to make a cash contribution. We've made voluntary cash contributions of $100 million in 2015 and I think we did the same thing in 2014. We haven't made the -- we don't need to make a decision in '16 until September before we file our tax re
componenttext: We do not need to make a cash contribution. We've made voluntary cash contributions of $100 million in 2015 and I think we did the same thing in 2014. We haven't made the -- we don't need to make a decision in '16 until September before we file our tax return. But at this point, nothing is actually required.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016

componenttext: This concludes our question-and-answer session for today. I would like to turn the conference back over to Mr. Glen Post for any closing remarks.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sayeed. We discussed with you last quarter that we believe that our investments in network and adjacent businesses along with our organizational changes and cost control efforts are beginning to take effect and produce positive results. We beli
componenttext: Thank you, Sayeed. We discussed with you last quarter that we believe that our investments in network and adjacent businesses along with our organizational changes and cost control efforts are beginning to take effect and produce positive results. We believe we can now clearly see the progress and that progress on our fourth quarter results. And we plan to continue to leverage and position our assets to help drive future revenue growth, EBITDA growth and shareholder value. And although our results may not be perfectly linear in the months ahead, I am confident that we're on a path to long-term growth and value creation. So thank you for joining our call today, and we look forward to speaking with you in the weeks ahead.
